results.title: La Belle Equipe = They Were Five
results.brief_description:
The fortune of five unemployed labourers take a radical turn for the better when they jointly win a 100,000 francs lottery prize. Jean, the self-appointed leader of the bunch, suggests they invest their money in a ‘guinguette’ (country pub cum outdoor entertainment) on the river Marne. Their dreams of instant success are dashed when Gina, Charles’ girlfriend, shows up demanding her portion of the winnings, then plots the destruction of Jean because he rebuffed her. The film was filmed with two endings. At the first release, the tragic ending chosen by Duvivier was a total flop. After 6 weeks, the film was withdrawn and re-released with a happy ending version. A very beautiful film which will be remembered as one of Duvivier’s finest. It is sensitive without sentimentality, original without effort, populist without vulgarity ; it starts with gaiety and we all feel gay. It ends tragically and our hearts rend. Simple people for a simple story, but with an added dimension of deep tragic poetry, for it shows how destiny can change and look like luck at first, then become fatality.” Source: L’Avant-Scene du Cinema, March 1996.

Credits: Producer, Arys Nissotti ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writer, Julien Duvivier, Charles Spaak ; photography, Jules Kruger, Marc Fossard ; music, Maurice Yvain ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Charles Vanel, Raymond Aimos, Charles Dorat, Viviane Romance, Raphael Medina, Fernand Charpin, Raymond Cordy, Charles Granval.

results.title: La Chinoise = the Chinese Girl
results.brief_description:
Veronique is a philosophy student. She is also the leader of a small group of friends who are interested in Marxist ideas. She lives in an apartment lined with shelves full of little red books. The group is made up of Guillaume, actor, Henri, student, Kirilov, a painter and Yvonne, prostitute. They are so taken by the external trappings of their cause — the posters, the Little Red Books, the by-rote chantings — that they seem not to grasp the true meaning of their political persuasion. Nor do they give any thought to the long-range ramifications of their terrorist activities. One day, Veronique proposes to assassinate a famous person. ‘La Chinoise’ is a montage film. Godard filmed each sequence as an autonomous piece, in no particular order. There was no preset idea about the chronology nor the ending. Some exterior scenes were shot on the Nanterre University Campus which was to become the starting point of the May 68 student movement.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard.
Cast: Anne Wiazemsky, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Juliet Berto, Michel Semeniako, Lex de Brujn, Omar Diop, Francis Jeanson.

results.title: Mille Sept Cent Quatre Vingt Neuf = 1789
results.creator_credit: Alexandre Mnouchkine, Georges Dancigers and Arianne Mnouchkine
results.brief_description:
This film records a production of the historical play ‘1789’, in which the Theatre du Soleil re-enacts the French Revolution and its aftermath. It shows how the Revolution served only to replace one set of rulers (the aristocrats and nobles) with another (the rich), an analysis which is clearly influenced by Marxist thinking. Filmed in June 1973 during 13 shows presented on the stage of ‘La Cartoucherie de Vincennes’. Best print: X0131.

Credits: Producers, Georges Dancigers, Alexandre Mnouchkine ; director, Arianne Mnouchkine ; writer, Ariane Mnouchkine ; photography, Jean-Paul Meurisse, Michel Lebon, Eduardo Serra, Bernard Zitzerman.
Cast: Philippe Caubere, Mario Gonzales, Genevieve Penchenat, Jean-Claude Penchenat.

results.title: Toni
results.brief_description:
Toni, an immigrant Italian worker in Provence, falls in love with Josepha but she is already engaged to somebody else. Out of spite, he takes up with Marie and both weddings are celebrated on the same day. Toni and Josepha meet up years later, both unhappy in their respectives mariages. The result is a crime of passion. Following the example of Marcel Pagnol, Renoir completely abandoned the studio and filmed exclusively outdoors and in genuine interiors in the Midi, using authentic sound and actors from the region. The film is remarkable for its avoidance of the melodramatic, the depth and fluidity of the camerawork and the feeling for figures in a landscape. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Jean Renoir, Carl Einstein ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, Paul Bozzi.
Cast: Charles Blavette, Jenny Helia, Edouard Delmont, Max Dalban, Andrex, Celia Montalvan.

results.title: Le Crime de Monsieur Lange = Crime of Monsieur Lange
results.creator_credit: Andre Halley des Fontaines and Jean Renoir
results.brief_description:
Lange is an author of wild west novels. When the owner of the company that publishes Lange’s works absconds with the company funds, Lange rallies the employees together to create their own publishing house. The publisher returns, disguised as a priest, and demands a share of the profits. Lange responds by killing him. The grateful employees help Lange to escape prosecution, allowing him to leave the country with his lovely fiancee. It is a joyous film, just as the Popular Front was a joyous movement, happy in the belief that living and working conditions could be changed for the better and fascism resisted at home and abroad. Exploitation (including sexual exploitation) are represented as the product of authoritarian capitalism, here represented by the publisher. Lange’s crime is what the poet W. H. Auden deemed a ‘necessary murder’. It is committed to prevent the destruction of the new world that has been built by a mini ‘Popular Front’ of progressive capitalists and workers by hand and by brain. When the film was re-released in the 1960’s, more attention was paid to its formal qualities (the staging of action in depth, an apparent 360 degree pan spotted by the great French critic Andre Bazin) than its political content.

Credits: Producer, Andre Halley des Fontaines ; director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Jean Renoir, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; music, Jean Wiener, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Jean Castanyer ; editor, Marguerite Houlle-Renoir.
Cast: Rene Lefevre, Jules Berry, Fiorelle, Nadia Sibirskaia, Henri Guisol, Sylvia Bataille, Maurice Baquet, Jean Daste, Marcel Levesque, Marcel Duhamel.

results.title: The Nun's story
results.creator_credit: Fred Zimmerman, Henry Blanke and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This story begins in 1930 with Sister Luke’s (Audrey Hepburn) journey from postulant to nun. Of her solemn vows of poverty, chastity, silence and obedience, Sister Luke knows the last will be the most difficult to achieve. Her strong will and intellectual pride, qualities destined to make her a brilliant nurse, threaten to undermine her holy calling. Unable to be obedient to her heart, Sister Luke comes perilously close to breaking. Highlighted by Audrey Hepburn’s performance, this film received eight Academy Award Nominations and also stars, Peter Finch, Dame Edith Evans, Dame Peggy Ashcroft, Dean Jagger and Mildred Dunnock.

results.title: Serie Noire
results.brief_description:
Frank Poupart is 30 year old loser who works as a door-to-door salesman in a dreary suburban wasteland. While doing his rounds, he sells a dressing gown to an old woman. The woman says she can’t pay but offers Frank to spend time with her teenage niece as a ‘compensation’. Mona and Frank become lovers, and both of them see a way out of their impoverished dead-end existences when Mona tells him that her aunt has a large stash of money hidden away. Director Alain Corneau cited Fritz Lang and American film noir as major influences for this film. The setting of ‘Serie Noire’ is bleak and wintry: vacant lots and blocks of flats, deserted except for the central characters. Much of the film is shot in shabby interiors or in Frank’s car, itself a restricted space from which he cannot escape. The soundtrack adds to the sense of realism, comprising the rumble of thunder and traffic, and incessant pop music from the radios which are found in almost every scene. Perec [the scriptwriter] has Frank speak a mixture of French backslang (le verlan) and street slang, combined with Anglicisms and spoonerisms. As Corneau remarked: “The challenge was to give an appearance of naturalism, but at all costs to avoid succumbing to it: we had to do something totally unrealistic.” Consequently, when Frank tries to express himself, he is at odds with reality, and in his mouth even the most banal language is turned around and used obliquely. Frank’s monologues, uttered in despair or frenzy while imprisoned in his car, are his own attempt to talk himself away from ‘la zone’.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French Cinema: an introduction’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Maurice Bernart ; director, Alain Corneau ; writers, Georges Perec, Alain Corneau ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Duke Ellington, Juan Tizol.
Cast: Patrick Dewaere, Myriam Boyer, Bernard Blier, Marie Trintignant, Andreas Katsulas, Jeanne Herviale.

results.title: Un Singe En Hiver = a Monkey in Winter
results.creator_credit: Georges Vallon, Jacques Bar and Henri Verneuil
results.brief_description:
Albert Quentin, who used to be a colonial soldier in China, is now living a peaceful life as an inn keeper in Normandy with Suzanne, his wife. One of Albert’s pleasure in life is to drink until he is transported back to his memeories of China. After surviving miraculously the bombings and the Allied landing in Normandy, Albert swears never to drink again and settles into a life of domestic routine and quiet boredom. Fifteen years later, a client arrive at the inn. His name is Gabriel Fouquet and he drinks to forget a failed marriage.

Credits: Producers, Jacques Bar, Georges Vallon ; director, Henri Verneuil ; writer, Michel Audiard, Francois Boyer ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Michel Magne ; assistant director, Claude Pinoteau, Costa Gavras.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Gabin, Suzanne Flon, Gabrielle Dorziat, Paul Frankeur, Noel Roquevert.

results.title: Une femme est une femme = a woman is a woman (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description:
A nightclub stripper wants to have a baby and settle down with her lover. When he refuses, she turns to his best friend. Godard’s third film is also one of his most light hearted and his first in colour and Cinemascope. Although there are the usual references, jump cuts and film quotes the films looks like an homage to the MGM musical. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1961: Best Actress for Anna Karina.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Michel Legrand ; art direction, Bernard Evein.
Cast: Anna Karina, Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean-Claude Brialy, Nicole Paquin, Dominique Zardi, Ernest Menzer, Henri Attal.

results.description:
A nightclub stripper wants to have a baby and settle down with her lover. When he refuses, she turns to his best friend. Godard’s third film is also one of his most light hearted and his first in colour and Cinemascope. Although there are the usual references, jump cuts and film quotes the films looks like an homage to the MGM musical. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1961: Best Actress for Anna Karina.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Michel Legrand ; art direction, Bernard Evein.
Cast: Anna Karina, Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean-Claude Brialy, Nicole Paquin, Dominique Zardi, Ernest Menzer, Henri Attal.

results.title: Si Versailles M'etait Conte = Affairs in Versailles
results.brief_description:
Shot entirely on location at the Chateau de Versailles, ‘Si Versailles…’ tells, Guitry-style, the story of the famous castle - from humble beginings as a hunting pavillion to classic splendour - and of the many events, affairs and gatherings it hosted. This is a typical Guitry production with a stellar cast, dozens of cameos and more one liners and ‘bonts mots’ than a ‘90s sitcom. As usual Guitry makes light of history, mixing major historical events and sexy anecdotes, while playing the central role of Louis XIV. Although it is an historical film, ‘Si Versailles …’ is ladden with anachronisms and factual errors. A share of the profits of the film went to the restoration and upkeep of the castle.

Credits: Producer, Clement Duhour ; director, Sacha Guitry ; writer, Sacha Guitry ; photography, Pierre Montazel ; music, Jean Francaix ; art direction, Rene Renoux.
Cast: Sacha Guitry, Michel Auclair, Jean-Pierre Aumont, Jean-Louis Barrault, Jeanne Boitel, Gilbert Boka, Bourvil, Pauline Carton, Gino Cervi, Jean Chevrier, Aime Clariond, Claudette Colbert, Nicole Courcel, Danielle Delorme, Jean Desailly, Renee Devi
